25.text: Several uranium resources have previously been defined in the Lake Raeside drainage

26.text: system  to  the  west  of  Company  Well.  The  principal  one  being  the  Peninsula  deposit

27.text: where an Inferred Resource of 6.7Mt at 0.253 Kg/t U3O8 has been delineated (Minedex).

30.text: exploration  has  defined  substantial  calcrete  deposits  at  the  Six-Ten  Calcrete  deposit

 Sampling program (Bradley et. al., 1995), lie within or proximal to the tenement, Figure 2.  
 The significant anomalism detected provides a strong indication of uranium mineralization

18.text: Hill Mining NL’s report contains a brief summary of these activities (Hampton Hill, 1995).

20.text: During 1993 Aurora Gold (WA) Ltd. evaluated the adjacent Six-Ten Calcrete Project as

21.text: a possible source of lime for the nearby Harbour Lights Biox Plant. RAB drilling, calcrete

22.text: laboratory test work and Bond Ball Mill tests were undertaken.  Two subcropping calcrete

23.text: deposits  were  defined:  the  11200N  Deposit  and  the  12400N  Deposit.  The  highly

24.text: weathered portion of the 11200N Deposit was considered the most suitable for use in the

25.text: Biox  Plant,  and  an  inferred  resource  of  200  000t  (1.5m  av.  thickness,  SG=2.7)  was

26.text: defined (Newton-Smith, 1993). No resource was calculated for the 12400N Deposit. The

27.text: test work indicated that “…. although the calcrete would be suitable as a part supplement

28.text: to  lime  in  the  Biox  Plant  it  would  require  crushing  and  grinding  before  use.”  However,

29.text: minor modifications to the Biox Plant and limited supplies of sulphide concentrates made

30.text: it  uneconomic  to  proceed  with  the  substitution  of  calcrete  for  lime  and  the  tenements

33.text: During 1996 and 1997 Messrs T.P. and A.P. Stehn held the Six-Ten Calcrete Project.

34.text: Although field reconnaissance work indicated significant potential to double the 200 000t

text:
The  majority  of  previous  exploration  programs  have  focused  upon  the  gold  potential 
 (alluvial/deep  leads  and  granitic  shear  hosted  extensions/splays  from  the  major  NNW 
 trending Gwalia-Harbour Lights-Gold Blocks line of mineralisation) of the area. Hampton 
 Hill Mining NL’s report contains a brief summary of these activities (Hampton Hill, 1995). 
 During 1993 Aurora Gold (WA) Ltd. evaluated the adjacent Six-Ten Calcrete Project as 
 a possible source of lime for the nearby Harbour Lights Biox Plant. RAB drilling, calcrete 
 laboratory test work and Bond Ball Mill tests were undertaken.  Two subcropping calcrete 
 deposits  were  defined:  the  11200N  Deposit  and  the  12400N  Deposit.  The  highly 
 weathered portion of the 11200N Deposit was considered the most suitable for use in the 
 Biox  Plant,  and  an  inferred  resource  of  200  000t  (1.5m  av.  thickness,  SG=2.7)  was 
 defined (Newton-Smith, 1993). No resource was calculated for the 12400N Deposit. The 
 test work indicated that “…. although the calcrete would be suitable as a part supplement 
 to  lime  in  the  Biox  Plant  it  would  require  crushing  and  grinding  before  use.”  However, 
 minor modifications to the Biox Plant and limited supplies of sulphide concentrates made 
 it  uneconomic  to  proceed  with  the  substitution  of  calcrete  for  lime  and  the  tenements 
 During 1996 and 1997 Messrs T.P. and A.P. Stehn held the Six-Ten Calcrete Project. 
 Although field reconnaissance work indicated significant potential to double the 200 000t

35.text: resource, no further work appears to have been undertaken (Sullivan, 1998).

37.text: From 1991 to 2000 the general area was explored for diamonds by several companies.
